projecttitle: Minimum Environmental Flow for Hydropower Projects in Bhutan, Final Phase
project_descrip: Short: MINIMUM ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW FOR HYDROPOWER PROJECTS IN BHUTAN, FINAL PHASE Long: The overall objective of the project is to minimize the negative impact on the environment from developmental activities such as hydropower plants. The project aims to consolidate achievements made in the previous phase by further  institutionalizing the environmental flow (E-Flow) utility beyond run-of-the-river hydropower plants development, which involves hydropower peaking, abstraction and diversion of natural watercourses such as for drinking and irrigation. In  addition, the project will integrate the study and analysis of E-Flows into the curriculum of educational institutes and establish robust institutional capacities. Thereby the project will contribute to reducing the negative impacts of  development activities on the ecological integrity of the aquatic ecosystems and river corridors. It will provide important insights and build capacities to better strike the delicate balance between economic development and generating  revenue on the one hand and ensuring minimal effects to the country's environment on the other hand.
shortdescription: MINIMUM ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW FOR HYDROPOWER PROJECTS IN BHUTAN, FINAL PHASE
longdescription: The overall objective of the project is to minimize the negative impact on the environment from developmental activities such as hydropower plants. The project aims to consolidate achievements made in the previous phase by further  institutionalizing the environmental flow (E-Flow) utility beyond run-of-the-river hydropower plants development, which involves hydropower peaking, abstraction and diversion of natural watercourses such as for drinking and irrigation. In  addition, the project will integrate the study and analysis of E-Flows into the curriculum of educational institutes and establish robust institutional capacities. Thereby the project will contribute to reducing the negative impacts of  development activities on the ecological integrity of the aquatic ecosystems and river corridors. It will provide important insights and build capacities to better strike the delicate balance between economic development and generating  revenue on the one hand and ensuring minimal effects to the country's environment on the other hand.

projecttitle: Water means life / Burkina Faso
project_descrip: Short: WATER MEANS LIFE / BURKINA FASO Long: The aim of the project is to sustainably improve the living conditions of the people dwelling in the outskirts of the city and to ensure long-term water supply. For this purpose, a water reservoir and a well will be built. In order to involve the  local population, a water committee will be set up whose members will be responsible for the maintenance of the technical facilities in the coming years. The implementation of hygiene training will also improve people's overall health. In  addition to supplying the population with drinking water, part of the water will also be used for irrigation of nearby agricultural areas. With the additional water, the cultivation of vegetables in the region can be intensified and the  nutritional situation improved. With the new well, the women will be relieved, as  long marches to or long waiting times at remote waterholes are eliminated.
shortdescription: WATER MEANS LIFE / BURKINA FASO
longdescription: The aim of the project is to sustainably improve the living conditions of the people dwelling in the outskirts of the city and to ensure long-term water supply. projecttitle: Irrigation system and solar power for notre terre - Artemisia cultivation in Burkina Faso
project_descrip: Short: IRRIGATION SYSTEM AND SOLAR POWER FOR NOTRE TERRE - ARTEMISIA CULTIVATION IN BURKINA FASO Long: The project notre terre was launched in 2021 in Loffing, a village near Dano in Burkina Faso. The father of two project members provided a plot of land of about 4 ha, which was leased by the newly founded association notre terre for 99 years.  The overall project notre terre (translated our earth) mainly includes the cultivation of Artemisia annua for the prophylaxis and treatment of malaria and other local diseases. For this purpose, a well has already been drilled (mainly  with the project manager's own funds, some donations, but also with financial support from ADA), a water elevated tank has been set up, a residential building and a storage building have been built. Small-scale cultivation of Artemisia annua  began as early as 2021 in order to learn about the plant's growth, maturation period, and water requirements in this region. The planned large-scale, year-round cultivation of Artemisia annua on about 3 ha in this region can only be managed  in the long term with a good irrigation system. At best, about 30,000 plants can be harvested annually on this area. This can contribute enormously to the treatment of malaria in this region, considering that the tea from the leaves of one  well-grown plant can help up to 8 adult people (and about twice as many children) to cure malaria. The current core project includes an irrigation system, along the lines of drip irrigation, but with one controller and more water per plant  (pure drip irrigation would not be sufficient) and a solar power system (incl. inverter and batteries for solar power storage and use in the buildings).  Solar panels were thankfully provided by the company Sonnenkraft. The well's flow rate  of 9 m³/h and the reservoir of the elevated tank are sufficient for irrigation. Since the previous investments in the project notre terre have used a substantial part of the of the private financial reserves of the project leader, financial  support will hopefully provided to build the irrigation system and to use the solar power for the residential and storage buildings also. Notre terre is help for self-help, connects people, gives courage to responsibility, medicinal plants  produced and used locally, affordable for everyone and affordable and usable for everyone.
shortdescription: IRRIGATION SYSTEM AND SOLAR POWER FOR NOTRE TERRE - ARTEMISIA CULTIVATION IN BURKINA FASO
longdescription: The project notre terre was launched in 2021 in Loffing, a village near Dano in Burkina Faso. The father of two project members provided a plot of land of about 4 ha, which was leased by the newly founded association notre terre for 99 years.  The overall project notre terre (translated our earth) mainly includes the cultivation of Artemisia annua for the prophylaxis and treatment of malaria and other local diseases. For this purpose, a well has already been drilled (mainly  with the project manager's own funds, some donations, but also with financial support from ADA), a water elevated tank has been set up, a residential building and a storage building have been built. Small-scale cultivation of Artemisia annua  began as early as 2021 in order to learn about the plant's growth, maturation period, and water requirements in this region. The planned large-scale, year-round cultivation of Artemisia annua on about 3 ha in this region can only be managed  in the long term with a good irrigation system. At best, about 30,000 plants can be harvested annually on this area. This can contribute enormously to the treatment of malaria in this region, considering that the tea from the leaves of one  well-grown plant can help up to 8 adult people (and about twice as many children) to cure malaria. The current core project includes an irrigation system, along the lines of drip irrigation, but with one controller and more water per plant  (pure drip irrigation would not be sufficient) and a solar power system (incl. inverter and batteries for solar power storage and use in the buildings).  Solar panels were thankfully provided by the company Sonnenkraft. The well's flow rate  of 9 m³/h and the reservoir of the elevated tank are sufficient for irrigation. Since the previous investments in the project notre terre have used a substantial part of the of the private financial reserves of the project leader, financial  support will hopefully provided to build the irrigation system and to use the solar power for the residential and storage buildings also. Notre terre is help for self-help, connects people, gives courage to responsibility, medicinal plants  produced and used locally, affordable for everyone and affordable and usable for everyone.

projecttitle: Climate-smart interventions for improved livelihoods
project_descrip: Short: CLIMATE-SMART INTERVENTIONS FOR IMPROVED LIVELIHOODS Long: The aim of the project is to promote the sustainable development of rural smallholders in Lubulini and Somntongo in the east / south-east of the country. Thanks to improved access to water through the collection of (rain) water, families in need  can grow climate-friendly and nutritious agricultural products in irrigated gardens.
shortdescription: CLIMATE-SMART INTERVENTIONS FOR IMPROVED LIVELIHOODS
geography: Lowveld Region and Lubombo Plateau, Lubulini and Somntongo constituencies
longdescription: The aim of the project is to promote the sustainable development of rural smallholders in Lubulini and Somntongo in the east / south-east of the country. Thanks to improved access to water through the collection of (rain) water, families in need  can grow climate-friendly and nutritious agricultural products in irrigated gardens.

projecttitle: Improved water, sanitation & hygiene (WASH) and Resilience in Amhara, Ethiopia (IWRA)
project_descrip: Short: IMPROVED WATER, SANITATION & HYGIENE (WASH) AND RESILIENCE IN AMHARA, ETHIOPIA (IWRA) Long: Improvement of the resilience of chronically food insecure households in East and West Belesa woredas in the Amhara regional state. The purpose is twofold: 1) to increase household access to water, sanitation and hygiene by improving irrigation  management and environmental conservation in the communities and 2) to use water resources as an entry point to empower women, girls and people with disabilities to affect lasting change in the community.
shortdescription: IMPROVED WATER, SANITATION & HYGIENE (WASH) AND RESILIENCE IN AMHARA, ETHIOPIA (IWRA)
longdescription: Improvement of the resilience of chronically food insecure households in East and West Belesa woredas in the Amhara regional state. The purpose is twofold: 1) to increase household access to water, sanitation and hygiene by improving irrigation  management and environmental conservation in the communities and 2) to use water resources as an entry point to empower women, girls and people with disabilities to affect lasting change in the community.

projecttitle: Agricultural project for women in Bale
project_descrip: Short: AGRICULTURAL PROJECT FOR WOMEN IN BALE Long: The central topic is empowerment of women. Women are encouraged to earn their own income using new agricultural techniques. They are trained for this and given the necessary equipment, and are strengthened by the establishment of a cooperative.  The most important factors are relief from heavy work such as collecting wood and carrying water, learning new land management techniques, improving the housing situation and health, family planning and improving nutrition through sustainable  agriculture. Local village committees (community based organizations) in coordination with SOSSE have selected the three villages and from them, according to the defined target groups, the women. The aim of the project is: 1) 120 women will  be formed into a cooperative under the guidance of SOSSE and, depending on their interests, educational background and personal situation, will receive training in agricultural work with cereals or vegetables, as well as in trade, business  basics and banking. Workshops for family planning, prevention of HIV and COVID by engineers of SOSSE or cooperation partners (see point 4.2) are part of the program. 2) Construction measures: a) A granary will be built. The storage of fruits  or grains is not yet anchored in the nomadic tradition of Ethiopian agriculture. On the one hand, it is important to secure food in the long term, but also to be able to wait for the best market situation before selling. b) House wells or  household ponds are built to store rainwater. They provide drinking water and irrigation for home gardens. This saves the women hours of walking to water points. c) Small gardens and home gardens with composting will be established. These are  used for self-supply and also for marketing. The production of compost is hardly known in in this region, but it enables the cultivation of fruits that would otherwise not grow or not thrive in the barren soil of this region. d) Energy-saving  Injera ovens are being built. In contrast to the traditional open fire, they are heated with electricity. Injera are flat cakes made of teff flour and are the are the most important food source in Ethiopia.  e) Micro - solar plants for  the light current and Injera ovens are established. The positive effects of these ovens are that it reduce the hard work of collecting wood, reduce the health damaging smoke in the huts and relieve the forest soil.
shortdescription: AGRICULTURAL PROJECT FOR WOMEN IN BALE
longdescription: The central topic is empowerment of women. Women are encouraged to earn their own income using new agricultural techniques. They are trained for this and given the necessary equipment, and are strengthened by the establishment of a cooperative.  The most important factors are relief from heavy work such as collecting wood and carrying water, learning new land management techniques, improving the housing situation and health, family planning and improving nutrition through sustainable  agriculture. Local village committees (community based organizations) in coordination with SOSSE have selected the three villages and from them, according to the defined target groups, the women. The aim of the project is: 1) 120 women will  be formed into a cooperative under the guidance of SOSSE and, depending on their interests, educational background and personal situation, will receive training in agricultural work with cereals or vegetables, as well as in trade, business  basics and banking. Workshops for family planning, prevention of HIV and COVID by engineers of SOSSE or cooperation partners (see point 4.2) are part of the program. 2) Construction measures: a) A granary will be built. The storage of fruits  or grains is not yet anchored in the nomadic tradition of Ethiopian agriculture. On the one hand, it is important to secure food in the long term, but also to be able to wait for the best market situation before selling. b) House wells or  household ponds are built to store rainwater. The positive effects of these ovens are that it reduce the hard work of collecting wood, reduce the health damaging smoke in the huts and relieve the forest soil.

projecttitle: Promoting Agricultural Productivity of Smallholder Farmers in Sofala Contribution 2016
project_descrip: Short: PROMOTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY OF SMALLHOLDER FARMERS IN SOFALA CONTRIBUTION 2016 Long: Contribution to increased productivity of family farms as well as enhanced food and nutrition security through improved technologies and services for agricultural production, processing and marketing. The ADC contribution will support the efforts  to ensure food and nutritional security in Sofala Province and is therefore concentrated in the following priority areas:-irrigation (promote improved technologies for agricultural production)-local seed production (promotion and supply of certified seeds and vegetative material for production)-production of vegetables and post-harvest conservation (promote increased household productivity and integration in local markets)-transfer of technology (training of technicians and producers in production of seeds, conservation agriculture and management of irrigation systems).

agencyname: FM of Education, Science and Research
projecttitle: Promotion of an innovative and green slope protection system (GreenPro)
project_descrip: Short: PROMOTION OF AN INNOVATIVE AND GREEN SLOPE PROTECTION SYSTEM (GREENPRO) Long: Number and intensity of natural disasters have been increasing in mountainous countries like Nepal and Austria. In a developing country like Nepal, the intensity of natural disasters are even more due to weakly monitored infrastructure  development activities such as constructions of roads, buildings irrigation channels, telecommunication towers, hydropower projects etc. Almost every family living on hills and mountains is vulnerable to landslide, flood, debris flow and  earthquake induced landslides disasters. Due to increasing number of landslides incidents every year, it has become routine or customary to bear the loss of hundreds of lives and property worth millions of dollars due to landslides and  floods. In order to mitigate the human induced and rainfall triggered natural disasters, it is necessary to implement appropriate preventive and curative measures against slope failure, soil erosion and flooding. Soil nailing is an economical  and efficient reinforcement technique used as a remedial measure in unstable natural slopes or as retraining structure for excavated slopes. In comparison with other retaining protection structures, soil nailing permits to reduce the  excavated fill soil volume, saving construction materials and realization time. There are basically two concerns about the application of soil nailing, first is in its analysis and design and second is about the use of materials. In order to  make an innovative construction practice and to make it more cost effective, environment friendly and sustainable, a right choice of facing and an appropriate design of soil nails are very important. Regarding the analysis and design of soil  nails, several national codes or guidelines exist. But the role of facing elements in controlling the deformation of excavated front or the overall stability of slope is not yet completely understood (Sanvitale et al, 2013).The stiffness of  facing strongly influences the characteristics of tensile force distribution, such as for a slope of two lateral segments, the tensile force at the connection (nail head) of nail with facing, and the location of maximum traction on the  soil-nail-facing system. (Sanvitale et al, 2013). Most of the conventional soil nailing with shotcrete, precast concrete or metal facing elements are generally costly and do not offer a 'Green' slope. The flexible facing elements do offer  some possibilities to grow some plants on the slope but have some disadvantages e.g. bulging or punching at nail heads and are not suitable to control surface erosion and local shear failure. In the above context, the soil nailing system with  semi-flexible 3-dimensional galvanized steel mat (popular as KRISMER® system in Europe) is a high-quality construction system which has proved itself one of the best solutions to stabilize slopes and embankments. Although, the functioning of  soil nailing with semi flexible 3D mat has been verified by different experiments and real site assessments, the act
shortdescription: PROMOTION OF AN INNOVATIVE AND GREEN SLOPE PROTECTION SYSTEM (GREENPRO)

projecttitle: Construction of a kindergarten in Rewsero and a rainwater collection system in Nyanza
project_descrip: Short: CONSTRUCTION OF A KINDERGARTEN IN REWSERO AND A RAINWATER COLLECTION SYSTEM IN NYANZA Long: The establishment of a kindergarten in Rewsero is intended to improve educational opportunities for around 100 children. The kindergarten fees and the costs for a warm meal are staggered depending on the family income situation, with these costs  for the poorest (cat. I and II) being borne by the municipality. The municipality also bears the personnel costs for educational support. The kindergarten building becomes the property of the municipality. Furthermore, the construction of a  rainwater collection system (2 tanks each 2,500 l) in Nyanza is to make water available for the operation of the toilets, for the building cleaning of the kindergarten and the adjoining school as well as for the irrigation of a school  garden.
shortdescription: CONSTRUCTION OF A KINDERGARTEN IN REWSERO AND A RAINWATER COLLECTION SYSTEM IN NYANZA

projecttitle: Revitalization of the village of Kassel in Kafountine
project_descrip: Short: REVITALIZATION OF THE VILLAGE OF KASSEL IN KAFOUNTINE Long: In the village of Kassel, which belongs to the municipality of Kafountine, live about 300 inhabitants, including 120 women and their children. It is about these 120 women and their families that this project of revitalization of the village is  about. They do the hard work of harvesting oysters in the mangroves, sometimes standing up to their bellies in water every day. They protect their hands with rags and use small wooden boats to bring their harvest ashore in tubs. There, other  women are waiting for further processing. They, too, sit on a stool all day with their children and separate the oysters from their shells. Since the old well in the village no longer works, drinking water has to be bought in Kafountine, 10  km away, filled into canisters and transported in. The income from the sale of the shells has to be spent mainly on the purchase and transport of drinking water from Kafountine. That leaves hardly anything to live on. The only small school  was closed because there is no water for sanitation, etc. Within the revitalization project, it is planned to create a borehole with a solar pump, rehabilitate the school building and add a class, renovate the sanitary facilities and provide  furniture, and lay water pipes to the fields, so that the women have more money left from selling oysters for their families, as well as are able to grow, irrigate and sell their own fruits and vegetables.
shortdescription: REVITALIZATION OF THE VILLAGE OF KASSEL IN KAFOUNTINE
longdescription: In the village of Kassel, which belongs to the municipality of Kafountine, live about 300 inhabitants, including 120 women and their children. It is about these 120 women and their families that this project of revitalization of the village is  about. They do the hard work of harvesting oysters in the mangroves, sometimes standing up to their bellies in water every day. They protect their hands with rags and use small wooden boats to bring their harvest ashore in tubs. There, other  women are waiting for further processing. They, too, sit on a stool all day with their children and separate the oysters from their shells. Since the old well in the village no longer works, drinking water has to be bought in Kafountine, 10  km away, filled into canisters and transported in. The income from the sale of the shells has to be spent mainly on the purchase and transport of drinking water from Kafountine. That leaves hardly anything to live on. The only small school  was closed because there is no water for sanitation, etc. Within the revitalization project, it is planned to create a borehole with a solar pump, rehabilitate the school building and add a class, renovate the sanitary facilities and provide  furniture, and lay water pipes to the fields, so that the women have more money left from selling oysters for their families, as well as are able to grow, irrigate and sell their own fruits and vegetables.

projecttitle: PIDD II - Sustainable Agricultural & Local Development - SYMBIOSE
project_descrip: Short: PIDD II - SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL & LOCAL DEVELOPMENT - SYMBIOSE Long: In the new phase of the project, the sustainable improvement of agricultural production remains a major theme. This is done through greater control of production factors, especially irrigation and seeds for rice and vegetable cultivation.  However, the stronger focus of activities on agro-ecological principles is new here. The link between functional literacy (especially for women) and rural entrepreneurship, as well as the promotion of good nutritional habits through the  creation of a directory and the dissemination of foods with high nutritional value, are other new approaches in the project. In the direct target group are about 5,000 people from rural households rice and vegetable producers, women's groups,  entrepreneurs, community representatives,  in the districts of Nioro du Rip, Kaffrine, Mbirkilane
shortdescription: PIDD II - SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL & LOCAL DEVELOPMENT - SYMBIOSE
longdescription: In the new phase of the project, the sustainable improvement of agricultural production remains a major theme. This is done through greater control of production factors, especially irrigation and seeds for rice and vegetable cultivation.  However, the stronger focus of activities on agro-ecological principles is new here. The link between functional literacy (especially for women) and rural entrepreneurship, as well as the promotion of good nutritional habits through the  creation of a directory and the dissemination of foods with high nutritional value, are other new approaches in the project. In the direct target group are about 5,000 people from rural households rice and vegetable producers, women's groups,  entrepreneurs, community representatives,  in the districts of Nioro du Rip, Kaffrine, Mbirkilane

projecttitle: Clean water for the schools in Duru/Tansania
project_descrip: Short: CLEAN WATER FOR THE SCHOOLS IN DURU/TANSANIA Long: The watersupply in the settlement Endangwe in the municipalty Duru (District Babati) in the North of Tansania, will be strongly improved due to professional development of a water source and the installation of a water filter and a solar pump.  The water pipeline secures irrigation during drought and increases yield.Durch die professionelle Erschließung einer Wasserquelle, die Installation eines Wasserfilters und einer Solarpumpe konnte die Trinkwasserversorgung in der Siedlung Endangwe in der Gemeinde Duru (Bezirk Babati) im Norden Tansanias stark  verbessert werden. Zuvor bezogen die rund 600 Einwohner sowie auch in dieser Ortschaft untergebrachten Schulen (mit insgesamt 900 SchülerInnen) aus einem sumpfigen kleinen Tal mit fragilen Wasserquellen. Die Wasserleitung dient darüber hinaus  bei Dürre zur Bewässerung und steigert die Ernteerträge, die bisher oft nicht bis zur nächsten Ernte ausreichten.
shortdescription: CLEAN WATER FOR THE SCHOOLS IN DURU/TANSANIA

projecttitle: WP-UGA-JHB, Production, Processing, Packaging and Distribution of dehydrated vegetables, herbs and spices, Uganda
project_descrip: Short: WP-UGA-JHB, PRODUCTION, PROCESSING, PACKAGING AND DISTRIBUTION OF DEHYDRATED VEGETABLES, HERBS AND SPICES, UGANDA Long: The Belgian company JHB International Trade and Finance S.A., with decades of experience in international trade in cocoa, tea, coffee and spices, has been organising since 2007 together with the Ugandan company Sunshine Agro Products Ltd. (short:  Sunshine) and with currently 5,000 smallholder families, JHB International Trade and Finance S.A. organizes the cultivation of chili in Northwest Uganda and the export of dried chilies to Europe. The project objective is to increase the net  income from spice cultivation for the contract farmers by 59% through processing and direct marketing. The net income for the companies should increase from € 0.10 to € 4.00 per kg, which will enable further investments. In addition, seven  full-time and 320 part-time and seasonal jobs equivalent to 100 full-time positions will be created locally. The project will increase the number of supplying producers to 8,000 small farming families. The farmers receive continuous support  to improve farming methods, including targeted training in farm management, the introduction of simple irrigation systems and the start of organic certification. The product range is greatly expanded through the cultivation of many other  products.
shortdescription: WP-UGA-JHB, PRODUCTION, PROCESSING, PACKAGING AND DISTRIBUTION OF DEHYDRATED VEGETABLES, HERBS AND SPICES, UGANDA
longdescription: The Belgian company JHB International Trade and Finance S.A., with decades of experience in international trade in cocoa, tea, coffee and spices, has been organising since 2007 together with the Ugandan company Sunshine Agro Products Ltd. (short:  Sunshine) and with currently 5,000 smallholder families, JHB International Trade and Finance S.A. organizes the cultivation of chili in Northwest Uganda and the export of dried chilies to Europe. The project objective is to increase the net  income from spice cultivation for the contract farmers by 59% through processing and direct marketing. The net income for the companies should increase from € 0.10 to € 4.00 per kg, which will enable further investments. In addition, seven  full-time and 320 part-time and seasonal jobs equivalent to 100 full-time positions will be created locally. The project will increase the number of supplying producers to 8,000 small farming families. The farmers receive continuous support  to improve farming methods, including targeted training in farm management, the introduction of simple irrigation systems and the start of organic certification. The product range is greatly expanded through the cultivation of many other  products.

TRAINING Long: Securing of food supply, responsible/sparing use of water in areas threatened by drought, higher crop yields (plus 15-25%) despite significantly lower water consumption (irrigation efficiency doubled) - delivery of sprinkler systems including  assembly and training

longdescription: Securing of food supply, responsible/sparing use of water in areas threatened by drought, higher crop yields (plus 15-25%) despite significantly lower water consumption (irrigation efficiency doubled) - delivery of sprinkler systems including  assembly and training
